etymologies: late Middle English (denoting a settlement formed mainly of retired soldiers, acting as a garrison in newly conquered territory in the Roman Empire): from Latin colonia ‘settlement, farm’, from colonus ‘settler, farmer’, from colere ‘cultivate’

definitions: a country or area under the full or partial political control of another country, typically a distant one, and occupied by settlers from that country

examples.text: Japanese forces overran the French colony of Indo-China

shortDefinitions: country under political control of another country

definitions: a group of people living in a colony, consisting of the original settlers and their descendants and successors

examples.text: the colony looked forward to fifty or more years of autonomy

shortDefinitions: group of people living in colony

definitions: all the foreign countries or areas formerly under British political control

examples.text: many poachers were exiled to the colonies

shortDefinitions: foreign places formerly under British control
areas in North America that founded USA

definitions: a group of people of one nationality or ethnic group living in a foreign city or country

examples.text: the British colony in New York

shortDefinitions: group of one nationality living in foreign place

definitions: a place where a group of people with similar interests live together
shortDefinitions: place shared by group with same occupation or interest

definitions: a housing development or residential community, especially one originally constructed by an employer for its workers

examples.text: a large housing colony has already been built
one of Jaipur's largest residential colonies

definitions: a community of animals or plants of one kind living close together or forming a physically connected structure
shortDefinitions: community of animals or plants living together

definitions: a group of fungi or bacteria grown from a single spore or cell on a culture medium.
